Backlog in parole decisions
follows overhaul at agency

The revamped state Parole Board has voted to grant early release to 17 serious offenders, but has not notified the inmates or families of their victims. (Boston Globe)
  • Graphic Parole rates  |  Discuss What do you think?

High court takes up health law fight

The president's health care overhaul is front and center at the Supreme Court for hearings to determine the fate of a law extending insurance to millions. (AP, 10:19 a.m.)

Odor sickens 15 Logan Airport workers

A hazmat situation was declared in a bag room at Logan Airport after an odor coming from an open bag sent four workers to the hospital, officials said. (Globe, 10:05 a.m.)

Foxborough, Krafts battle over billboards

A disagreement over who controls a pair of billboards near Gillette Stadium is part of a bitter dispute between the town and The Kraft Group. (Boston Globe)

Need a teller at the ATM? Push the button

After years of customers doing their banking without human interaction, the next step could put people back into the picture. (Boston Globe)

Many are abandoning
sitting while working

Once quirky outliers in the office, employees who prefer to stand at their desks and in meetings are multiplying in corporate America.

Cardinal heads to a changing Cuba

Cardinal Sean O’Malley prepared to accompany Pope Benedict XVI this week to the communist state, where the Roman Catholic Church has been reborn.

Fiscal pinch casts shadow
on nuclear security push

Obama administration officials, citing fiscal restraints and a need to reassess the campaign, want to cut funding for a nuclear smuggling project by 65 percent.

FDA works to trim ‘alarm fatigue’

The FDA is intensifying its scrutiny of medical devices in an effort to reduce the hospital ‘‘alarm fatigue’’ that has been linked to hundreds of deaths nationally.

Vendor sues city over school lunches

A former provider of student lunches for the Boston public schools has alleged that the city violated public bidding laws by awarding a contract to a competitor.

Understanding autism

Science and medicine are catching up with parents’ understanding of the condition, and a more nuanced view is emerging: Autism is not just a brain problem.
Opinion | Juliette Kayyem

A new passage with not enough rules

The challenge for populations close to the Bering Sea is how to manage the traffic on an ocean they never dreamed would be so welcoming.
